I would change the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo in 1914. This event triggered the start of World War I, one of the deadliest conflicts in human history. By preventing the assassination, I believe the world could have avoided the war and saved countless lives.

I would change the outcome of the American Civil War. While the Union ultimately won the war, the process was brutal and resulted in the deaths of over 600,000 Americans. By changing the outcome, I believe the country could have healed more quickly and moved forward without the scars of such a devastating conflict.

I would change the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. While the fall of the wall was a significant event in the end of the Cold War, it also marked the beginning of a new era of uncertainty and change for Germany and the world. By preventing the wall from falling, I believe the world could have continued to maintain a stable balance of power.

I would change the outcome of the French Revolution. While the revolution ultimately led to the overthrow of the monarchy and the rise of Napoleon, it also resulted in a period of extreme violence and instability. By changing the outcome, I believe the world could have avoided the excesses of the revolution and moved forward with a more stable government.

I would change the outcome of the Cuban Missile Crisis in 1962. While the crisis was ultimately resolved peacefully, it was a close call and resulted in a significant increase in tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union. By preventing the crisis from occurring, I believe the world could have avoided a nuclear war and maintained a stable balance of power.
